description: 2 figures, one very small carrying a basket, in lower left corner standing on a bridge; 2 buildings near top; tall trees in middle ground and mountains in background; inscription and 2 seals in upper left corner
text: Xie Daoling, from Suzhou in Jiangsu province, was known for his bird-and-flower compositions as well as landscapes done in old styles. Much of his pictorial vocabulary was derived from Shen Zhou (1427-1509), founder of the Wu or Suzhou school of painting. Attended by a servant carrying a basket of herbs, a scholar pauses on a bridge beneath a pine tree gazing upwards toward his destination, a monastery visible in the mist of a distant valley. Gathering herbs, a practice pursued by both Daoists and Buddhists, was a favorite scholarly pastime. It provided an excuse to interact with nature, which in itself could be a meditative process. The inscription reads: During a spring day of the year 1612 of the Wanli reign, painted in the Chan (Buddhist) Grove at Vulture Peak by Xie Daoling of Wuchun (Suzhou).
title: Gathering Herbs
